Frears' Technicolor Tomfoolery
by David Dudley
"Costume Drama" is a term
often now consigned to a distant
past of day-glo Technicolor extravaganzas based on books you
never liked in high school.
Everybody talked like Emily
Bronte and wore fabulously illogical clothing. The men had
powdered wigs and make-up, the
women were bound in hoopskirts
and nightmarish trusses and carried small dogs on velvet pillows.
No one ever got shot. They were
unpleasant, turgid affairs, but
your parents liked them. Stephen
Frears's Dangerous Liaisons has
all of these things, and more. It's
got good ol' American actors
dressed like foppish Frenchpeople, heaving constrained breasts,
vengeful domineering women,
the occasional grimy peasant,
cunning references to semi-legal
sex acts, bloodletting, miscarriages, and full-frontal nudity.
Think of it as the Costume Drama
for the Nineties.
Director Frears, whose
previous credits have been limited
to the British independent cult hits
My Beautiful Laundrette and
Sammy and Rosie Get Laid (films
your parents probably didn't
like), has found himself helming
a mammoth $14 million AngloAmerican production that boasts
a trio of distinctively American
stars: Glenn Close, John
Malkovich, and Michelle
Pfeiffer.
The incongruity of these three
decked out in magnificently baroque, late 18th-century French
finery and acting like preRevolutionary aristocrats was apparently not lost on the director,

and thus he revels in the frills and
the foppery. He rubs your face in
it, makes a performance out of
the intricate rituals of fashion and
manners and the studied deception of appearance. The
fascinating opening sequence of
the film show Close and
Malkovich being primped and
powdered and garroted into their
elaborate garb by a hushed army
of servants, like performers
before a show or knights before
combat. The costume becomes
drama, and the characters are
both performers in their own personal operas and combatants vying for control.
The drama itself revolves
around the competitive intrigues
of Close's Marquise de Merteuil
and Malkovich's Vicomte de Valmont, two French aristocrats with
a taste for seduction and a lot of
time on their hands. Romance is
an intricate game of manipulation
and deceit, and they are both experienced players. Valmont's
quarry is one Madame de Tourval (Michelle Pfeiffer), a pillar of
Christian virtue and decency with
a distant husband. Valmont sees
in her the ultimate challenge to
his skills and makes a wager on
his eventual succcess with
Merteuil, who is meanwhile raising hell in other quarters of the
court with her own schemes.
Things get very convoluted, and
eventually everyone dies or goes
insane or otherwise pays the
wages of sin.
Liaisons is being heaped with
Academy Award nominations,
and it seems to have touched a
nerve in the fickle American
public in much the same way that
last year's Fatal Attraction did.
The comparison is inevitable and

not entirely undeserved, given the
presence of Glenn Close in a
superficially-similar role. "I was
born to dominate your sex and
avenge my own," she intones at
one point in the film, calling up
echoes of Attraction's vengeful
woman-as-vindicator persona.
But Close's Marquise is a cool
manipulator, not a knife-wielding
psychotic, and though her obsessions prove equally tragic, it is
somehow a more restrained, cunning performance. Caked in her
pale death-white makeup and
trussed into her hoop-skirt battle
armor, she is a picture of
bloodless, relentless cruelty—
antisexual where Fatal Attraction
was violently sexual.
John Malkovich's Vicomte de
Valmont has a certain fascination
all its own, if only for the often
clumsy spectacle of hearing the
consummate American actor
wrap his Midwestern drawl
around David Hampton's precise,
esoteric dialogue. It takes some
getting used to, but his serpentine
grace and understated approach
make him a commanding and
believable screen figure nevertheless. Michelle Pfeiffer looks
appropriately pale and winsome
in the less demanding role of
Madame de Tourval, but she has
none of the depth of the other
two. Her performance is largely
cold blue eyes and the occasional
wracked sob and heaving breast.
The script, written by Hampton from his own stage play, is
on Les Liaisons
based
Dangereuses, a scandalous 18thcentury novel by Choderlos de
Laclos that was banned after the
Revolution for its hearty depictions of aristocratic tomfoolery.
Hampton's screenplay is literate

those of stereotypical Poles,
Jews, and immigrants, all of
whom have nothing better to do
than scrap for money and, when
they fail, blame someone else.
Katz's portrayal is right on the
mark, though
Mushnik's
character is too one-dimensional
for Katz to develop it better. His
best scenes, too, are with
Seymour.
As Audrey, Kennedy overplays
her role, but the role deserves to
be overplayed. Kennedy's speaking and singing voices are sufficiently wispy, and the seemingly
uncharacteristic power her voice
takes on in "Suddenly Seymour"
accurately reflects Audrey's
discovery of an "ideal" in
Seymour, an ideal Audrey never
knew.
Kennedy is at her best in the
solo "Somewhere That's
Green," in which Audrey longs
to escape Skid Row for the grassy
elegance of the suburbs. To say
more would ruin the funniest line
in the song.
Golub plays the sadistic dentist
nicely. His voice and intonation
clearly reflect Orin's excesses,
and his facial expressions
highlight the wretched excess the
dentist preaches and practices.
Like Mushnik, Orin is a onedimensional character, but Golub
largely overcomes this handicap.
As the voice of Aldrey II, An-

dy Angelino does a good imitation of the Motown shriek the
script demands. The accent is difficult to master, but Angelino
does well except in the higher
ranges.
Since Little Shop is in part a
spoof of 1950s culture as well as
of B-movies and science fiction,
it has an obligatory female trio of
singers, the Plantlettes, who wear
dated dresses and hairdos.
The Plantlettes—Marci Anderson, Mary Kita, and Kara
Stein—have no business in Skid
Row other than to inject their
three-part harmonies into spots
when no one else is speaking, or
to offer shallow, unwanted advice
to Seymour. They are just, well,
always there.
That's a good thing. Anderson,
Kita, and Stein are good singers,
and funny because they always
turn up just when other characters
don't need them.
By and large, the show is a success. It's shortcomings result
largely from weaknesses in the
script, not in the acting. Yet in a
show whose songs are as funny
as its dialogue, these lapses pale.

Which came first, the chicken or the iguana?
by Ganesh Venkataraman Raj

.4.-

In 1874, Charles Darwin
published his theory of evolution,
in which he claimed that man had
evolved from apes. He cited
studies of external features showing physical similarities between
apes and man. However, Darwin
was unable to deduce the order of
evolution of most other species;
whether birds came from reptiles
or vice versa. Since then, the
evolutionary order has been
established to the level of species,
from fossil records, comparative
studies of internal and external
structures and, more recently, by
the molecular biology of proteins.
Hemoglobin is an oxygencarrying protein found in red
blood cells and free in blood.
Structurally, it is made up of four
distinct protein chains, two alpha
chains and two beta chains, which
are made of amino acids linked
linearly. All alpha chains have
some common amino acid sequences, but may differ in others.
Each chain also contains, at its
core, an iron atom that binds oxygen at the oxygen-rich lungs,
and releases it at oxygen-deficient
tissues.
In 1959, Max Perutz at Cambridge saw that alpha and beta
chains from horses and those
from sperm whales had the same
amino acid sequence. Perutz
theorized that hemoglobin from
horses and those from sperm
whales developed from a com-

mon genetic precursor. Perutz's
team and others analyzed
hemoglobin from more animals
and found common amino acid
sequences. For example, in all
animals, every hemoglobin chain
has a histidine amino acid at the
eighty-seventh position.
All alpha chains have identical
amino acids at 23 of their 141
positions, while beta chains have
the same amino acids in 20 out of
146 positions. If only mammalian
sequences are analyzed, then
identical amino acids can be
found at 50 out of 141 positions
in alpha chains, and Si out of 146
positions in beta chains. Alpha
chains of man and rhesus
monkeys differ by only 4 positions out of 141, cows and man
differ by 17, while sharks and
man differ by 99 amino acids.
Similar data supports Perutz's
general principle of evolution,
which states that the more closely related two species are, the
more similar the amino acid sequences of their proteins will be.
In all animals, hemoglobin performs the same function: it acts
as an oxygen carrier. Certain
amino acids are 'conserved' during evolution, because they are
necessary for the function and
structure of hemoglobin. These
amino acids cannot be replaced
by other amino acids, because
any change will impair the
hemoglobin's function. Individuals missing these amino
acids because of mutation will die

before they reproduce. For example, the iron atom, vital for oxygen transport, is held in place by
binding to the histidine at the
eighty-seventh position of both
alpha and beta chains. If histidine
were to be replaced by any other
amino acid, the iron atom would
not be held firmly in place. Any
change in the iron's position
makes oxygen less accessible.
Scientists use Perutz's general
principle of evolution to analyze
the number of differences between hemoglobin chains from
different species. Researchers
now believe that birds evolved
from primitive reptiles, that
whales are more evolved
creatures than platypuses, that
carp are closer in the evolutionary
tree to man than sharks, and so
on. Some plants, like soybeans,
have hemoglobin; their alpha
chains differ from that of humans
by 113 out of 141 amino acids.
Hence, from comparative
hemoglobin studies, we know that
plants and humans, though
separated from each other on the
evolutionary tree, have a common ancestor.
Scientists are attempting to take
this order a step further by looking at the source of the amino
acids. Amino acids are encoded
by specific genes that are passed
from parent to offspring.
Geneticists study the genes that
encode for the alpha and beta
chains. Studies have shown many
similarities in these genes,

especially those that encode for
vital amino acids. Many highly
conserved sequences are present
along with a number of moderately conserved sequences. Gene
studies are useful because scientists can find varying degrees of
conservation of genes and from
this draw more accurate conclusions about evolution of subspecies and other lower orders.
From gene studies, scientists
can also establish a time scale for
the evolutionary tree because
changes that lead to evolution occur at the level of the gene. Mutations change genes and are
responsible for the variation
among species. Scientists make a
time frame for each mutation by
comparing hemoglobin chains of
closely related species. If two
closely related species differ by
10 mutations, and if fossil records
show that the two species are ten
million years apart, then each
mutation must take on the average
a million years.
By making a time frame for
each mutation, scientists have
come up with a biological clock
to accompany the evolutionary
tree. The unique feature of the
clock is its varying speed;
sometimes, the rate of mutation
is high, but at other times, it is
almost negligible. The clock
allows for natural selection. For
example, if a mutation in one
gene is selected for by nature,
then it may trigger mutations in
other genes, thus speeding up the

clock. Similarly, if a mutation is
rejected by nature, then other
mutations may also be blocked,
slowing down the clock.
Geneticists using the biological
clock estimate that plants and
animals separated 500 million
years ago, that reptiles evolved
300 million years ago, that
primitive mammals evolved 100
million years ago, that monkeys
evolved less than 30 million years
ago, and that man evolved from
monkeys less than 15 million
years ago.
However, the evolutionary tree

to

Fencers finish third
Foilmen travel to MACs tomorrow
The men's fencing team
travelled to New York University this past weekend for the Second Annual UAA Fencing
Championships, hoping to improve on last year's third place
finish. However, its fate was the
same, as it placed third, behind
Brandeis and NYU. The Jays
were 2-2 on the day, beating the
University of Chicago 17-10 and
Case Western 21-6, while falling
at the hands of tournament champions Brandeis 18-9 and secondplace NYU, 19-8.
The foil team once again fenced well as it went .500 by
defeating Chicago 7-2 and Case
Western 6-3, while losing to
Brandeis 7-2 and NYU 8-1.
Senior co-captain David Cohen
was 8-4 in the team event and
placed seventh in the individual
competition. Freshman Rich
Millhiser posted a mark of 5-7
during the team competition and
placed eleventh individually,
while junior Mike Greenfield had
a record of 3-8 and placed fifteenth overall. Junior Yen Len
Tang placed tenth individually
while only going 0-1 during the
team round.
The Epee team was outstanding, as it finished second. The
Epeemen were 3-1, defeating
Case Western, Chicago, and
NYU by the scores of 9-0, 6-3,
and 6-3, respectively. Its only
loss came at the hands of
Brandeis, 6-3. Sophomores Tim
Train and Ian Held were spectacular, as they were 10-2 and 6-4
during the team event and placed
an impressive second and third,
respectively, in the individual
tournament. Senior co-captain
Bob Lee also fenced well,

finishing seventh individually and
posting a mark of 8-4 during the
team competition. Sophomore
Andrew Donnalley finished
eighth overall after a disappointing 0-2 in the team event.
The sabre team continued to
gain experience and came into its
own as it placed fourth overall.
Junior co-captain Andrew
Jablonowski finished sixth individually, while having a record
of 5-7 during the team rounds.
Junior Dave Howe posted a mark
of 6-6 in the team competition
while placing eleventh individually and sophomore John O'Connell continued to show improvement as he was 4-8 in the team
rounds and placed twelfth overall.
Sophomore Peter Kim placed sixteenth individually.
This weekend the team travels
to Haverfoid to try to defend its
MAC championship, which it has
held for the past five years. The
Jays' toughest competition for its
title will come from Rutgers,
Vassar, and William & Mary.
But Hopkins hopes its tough practice and season schedule will help
it "go for six." The following
weekend the Jays will host the second annual Division III National
Championship.
Again, Coach Dick Oles was
guardedly optimistic. "We'll
have to fence at the absolute top
of our game this year, all of us,
to keep the MAC title, "he said.
But there's no doubt whatsoever
in my mind that we have the
capability, particularly after the
epee team's great performance at
the UAA last week. We've improved, and we're hungry. It's
going to be a good tournament."

Blue Jays set sights on 1989 championship
by Josh Orenstein
Coach Don Zimmerman has a simple goal for the
1989 Hopkins lacrosse team: the National
Championship.
The Johns Hopkins University and Coach Zimmerman are very familiar with lacrosse championsips.
Entering its 107th season of intercollegiate lacrosse,
Hopkins has won or shared 42 National Championships. In five years as head coach, Zimmerman has
guided the Blue Jays to three titles.
Three returning All-Americans, including the nation's top defenseman and top goalkeeper, lead a very
talented Hopkins team on the drive to the National
Championship. The road will be filled with obstacles,
most notably tomorrow's opponent, top-ranked and
defending champion Syracuse University. Although
the Orangemen are the favorites to defeat Hopkins,
and ultimately to repeat as champs, Coach Zimmerman is confident of his team's ability.
ATTACK
"We have a more powerful offense this year,"
says Coach Zimmerman.
Sophomore Mike Panetta (in 1988, 10 goals, 4
assists) heads an attack which must compensate for
the loss to graduation of first-team All-America Mike
Morrill. Scoring a team-high 26 goals last season,
Morrill accounted for almost 25% of the Jays'
offense.
Panetta has the ability to be one of the top attackmen
in the country. He forces the action the most of
anyone we've had since [Craig] Bubier, maybe
more," says Zimmerman.
Senior Jeff Ihm (12 goals, 5 assists) and either
junior Jay Clarke or senior John Ciccarone will join
Panetta on the starting attack unit. Junior Scott Marr
and sophomre Mike Morrissey are experienced
players who should see considerable playing time.
Marr is the Jays' leading returning scorer with 28
points last season (12 goals, 16 assists.) Freshman
Jeff Wills (Linthicum, MD), a member of the extraman offensive unit, is one of four newcomers who
Coach Zimmerman expects to contribute immediately. Freshman Drew Burns (Severna Park, MD)
rounds out the attack.

"We're thin on defense," explains Coach Zimmerman. Zimmerman hopes that experience and
ability at the position will make up for the lack of

and junior Dave Howland for the season. Both will

Senior Dave Pietramala, first-team All-America

Seniors Steve Ciccarone and Greg Lilly team with

GOAL
Quint Kessenich is the premier goalkeeper in college lacrosse. Last year, as a sophomore, Kessenich
won first-team All-American honors and the C.
Markland Kelly Award as the nation's outstanding
goalkeeper in Division I lacrosse. Over the past two
years, the Jays have won 16 of the 18 games that
Kessenich has started.
"Quint looks as good now as he ever has. He has
done a tremendous job of preparing physically and
mentally for the Syracuse game and for the season,"
says Zimmerman.
Scott Giardina (Farmingdale, NY)and Ian Hobbs
(New Canaan, CT)are promising freshmen who will
back up Kessenich.

Coach Don Zimmerman is exicted about the 1989
season.
"This year we have more depth on the squad,"
said Zimmerman. "We're going at a good pace. We
will be ready for Syracuse, March 4th."
Tomorrow, Zimmerman and the Hopkins lacrosse
team face an unenviable task. The Jays open the 1989
season by playing a Syracuse team that appears even
better than the 1988 Orangemen.
Last year, in the season opener for both teams,
Syracuse trounced the Blue Jays at Homewood, 19-7.
The loss was the most one-sided in Zimmerman's
five years as head coach. The Orangemen then sailed on to a perfect 15-0 record and the National
Championship.
Syracuse's greatest weapon is the Gait twins. The
junior midfielders were both named first-team AllAmerica last season. Gary, consensus Player of the
Year, scored a record-breaking 70 goals; Paul netted 47.
"The impact they made last year on lacrosse was
as significant as any since Jim Brown," said Coach
Zimmerman. Syracuse alumnus Jim Brown, more
famous for his achievements on the football field,
is widely considered the greatest lacrosse player ever.
"The Gaits are excellent players, they're dominant. They have to be held in check," said Zimmerman. "It'll be tough for them to put together backto-back seasons like that."
With the Gaits, Attackman of the Year John
Zulberti, goalie Matt Palumb (the most valuable
player of the 1988 championship game), and four
other returning starters, the Orangemen are not only predicted to repeat as champions, they are expected
to. The team is generally considered unbeatable. But
Zimmerman believes there is a team that can defeat
Syracuse.
"We are aiming to win, and we can win." said
Zimmerman. He explained that Hopkins must control the tempo, not allowing the Orangemen to play
their fast-paced, running game, and must also hustle for groundballs.
In regard to last season's game, Zimmerman issued
the following statement: "Losing to Syracuse was
embarrassing enough, having people throw oranges
was humiliating. I expect the fans to show class and
respect for our opponents and our team."
In 1988, the Blue Jays did not reach the national
semifinals for the first time since 1975. The Hopkins
season ended at Homewood in the quarterfinals, as
Virginia upset the second-ranked Jays 11-10 in
overtime.
For Hopkins, the game was the second consecutive
overtime struggle. In the regular season finale, at
Homewood, the Jays needed an extra period to defeat
Towson State, 9-8.

Hopkins hosts defending national champion
By Patrick Furey
The Johns Hopkins Blue Jays once again will face
one of the nation's toughest lacrosse schedules,
beginning at home tomorrow against the defending
national champions, the Syracuse Orangemen. For
those of you who are regular readers of the NewsLetter, the following article is the lacrosse version
of Pat's Picks. Here is how I see the season shaping up for the Jays.

SYRACUSE
Saturday, March 4
Homewood Field
2:00 p.m.
Hopkins leads the series 10-5
This seems like a fairly easy pick. After all,this
is pretty much the same Syracuse that came to into
Homewood last year and rocked the Jays 19-7 en
route to an undefeated national championship. The
Orangemen are loaded, to say the least. The midfield is paced by the most prolific tandem to hit
lacrosse in quite some time, the Gait brothers. The
attack unit from last year returns intact, led by first

by Robert M. Brenner and Gopal Kowdley
With Eddie Murray transplanted to La-La Land,
and the remaining Orioles resembling a club from the
International League, Baltimore's top spring sports
draw remains the Blue Jays of Johns Hopkins University. Although last year ended in disappointing
fashion at the hands of Peter Sheehan and the Wahoos
of Virginia, the Blue Jays still managed to win nine
consecutive games against many of the best collegiate
lacrosse teams in the nation.
By now,even the freshmen realize that for the 1989
Jays to be victorious on Memorial Day in College
Park, they must fare better against the Syracuse
Orangemen, who last year invaded Homewood and
trounced Hopkins 19-7. The Orange steamrolled
through their remaining regular season encounters,
as well as the NCAA tournament, en route to the
National Championshop. However, as any Orioles
fan will tell you, this is indeed a new season, and
that means three months of lacrosse festivities to
tempt even the regulars of D-level. To try and provide you with insight into the Blue Jays competition,
here is our second annual Pre-season lacrosse poll
accompanied by our expert analyses
1) Syracuse Orangemen:
Led by juniors Gary and Paul Gait, the Orange
return all but two of their starters from last year's
undefeated squad. Coach Roy Simmons Jr. will rely heavily on the explosive Gaits, who at times seem
to elevate the game to new levels. Gary Gait's
statistics from last year catapulted him into a level
occupied by the greatest players ever, including
former Syracuse standout Jim Brown. Gait also added
personal innovation to the world of lacrosse with his
now famous "Air Gait" maneuver, which he introduced during last year's Final Four.
Besides the Gaits, Syracuse will count heavily on

a very experienced attack, including returning starters
Greg Burns, Jim Egan, and the colorful John "Z"
Zulberti. With an experienced second unit, as well
as an offensively-minded midfield, goal scoring
should continue in great numbers for Syracuse.
At midfield, the Orange lost speedster Keith Owens,
starter Brad Roos, as well as face-off specialist and
co-captain Bill Dirrigl. However, Rodney Dumpson,
Earl Hall, and junior-World player Freddie Amaya
are ready to establish themselves on the collegiate
level. Also, Joe Bonnaci, a two year starter at Navy,
has transferred to Syracuse.
With all of the blowouts and high scoring antics
provided by the Orange last year, many people
overlooked their exceptional defense. The close
defense of Mark Stopher, Jim McNamara, and Pat
McCabe returns to the Dome. A strong recruiting
class will provide insurance at the long stick position.
Returning in the net will be junior Matt Palumb,
who brings a 17-1 career record into 1989. Jerry
DeLorenzo was one of last year's most highly regarded high school players; he also participated in the
junior World games. He might well be the top backup goalie in the nation.
Of note is the fact that during last season, Syracuse
played all of their games on artificial turf. Playing
on turf allowed Syracuse to play a faster and more
explosive game than would have been possible on
grass, especially in foul conditions. This season,
however, they have six of their first eight games on
the road, with all but one played on natural grass.
Their opener at Homewood was the sole exception.

Led by returning first team All-Americans Dave

Rzempoluch. Junior Greg Kelly and sophomore Seth

starters Pietramala, Greg Lilly, and Steve Ciccarone.

sophomores Billy Dawn and Brian Voelker. Due to
knee injuries, both James DeTommaso and Dave
Howland will be sidelined for the entire '89 campaign, but they will both return for the 1990 season.
In goal resides junior Kessenich, who many consider the team's most valuable player. He will try
to duplicate his first team All-American selection in
his final two years of competition. He will be backed up by two promising freshmen, Scott Giardina

by Andy Prior
The Hopkins lacrosse season got off to a shaky
start. Just one month into the season, the disciplinary

additional players had created a sense of turmoil.
Despite these set-backs, the Blue Jays managed to
regroup for nine consecutive wins to finish the regular
season at 9-1, ranked second in NCAA Division
I. The Hopkins season ended abruptly, however,

University of Virginia in quarter-final play.

DeTommaso, had damaged furniture in the lobby of

first time that the Jays had lost by more than four
goals under his coaching. At one point during the
game the Jays were unable to score for 32:56.
Following the 19-7 blowout against Syracuse, three
Jays resigned from the squad for what were termed
personal reasons. The loss of starting attackman John
Ciccarone, starting midfielder John Dressel, and third
midfielder Mark Dressel cast serious doubts about
the ability of the Jays to perform only a month into

the lacrosse season.

A tribute to former coach Henry Ciccarone, Sr.
Courtesy of Hopkins Sports Information Dept.
All of us who loved and respected Henry Ciccarone
were shocked by the tragic news of his death on
November 16, 1988, at aye 50. Even though Chic
had suffered two previous heart attacks, there was
no doubt in any of our minds that he was going to
beat this illness. Chic almost always had a way to
beat the odds and to win—whether in sports, games
of chance, or any type of competition. But this time
Chic lost the battle, and great sadness has come to
his family, his friends, and the entire lacrosse world
where he made an indelible mark.
Chic entered Hopkins in the fall of 1958. He played
on the freshman football team under Bob Scott, who
realized then that Chic was an outstanding athlete
and a dynamic leader. All of his teammates enjoyed
his outgoing personality and his great sense of humor.
He began his lacrosse career at Hopkins the following spring on the freshman team coached by Fred
Smith, who became one of Chic's staunchest supporters and his personal friend. Chic played three
years on the varsity football team for Wilson Fewster
and led the Blue Jays to Middle Atlantic Conference
championships in 1959 and 1960. He was named to
the All-Conference team as a single-wing tailback.
He called all the offensive plays and was the obvious
team leader. Chic ran the show on the lacrosse field
as well, and it was there that he really excelled. He
was an All-American midfielder during each of his
three years on the varsity, was team captain, and winner of just about every Hopkins award—Penniman
Award for the best midfielder, Turnbull-Reynolds
Award for leadership, Erlanger Award for the best
senior player, and selection to the All-Time Hopkins
lacrosse team.
When Chic finished his playing career in 1962,
athletic director Marshall Turner hired him as an
assistant coach in football, basketball, and lacrosse.
Chic was always at his best when the pressure was
on. Whether it was sending in the play on a crucial
fourth-down situation in football, or setting up the
last shot in a tied basketball or lacrosse game, Chic
thrived on making the tough decision. And he was
so good at it. Not too many people are aware that
Chic was the head coach of Hopkins varsity basketball for six years. His teams beat Loyola College
three times, and his 1967-68 team won the MAC
Southeast League championship.
After seven years on the athletic staff, Chic left
Homewood in the summer of 1969 for a position in
the business world. He did assist in coaching the '71

lacrosse team as a part-timer. When Marshall Turner
retired as athletic director and turned the job over
to Bob Scott in the summer of 1973, Chic was immediately called and asked to return as a full-time
assistant in 1974 and head coach in 1975.
He agreed and then proceeded to establish a truly
remarkable record over a nine-year period. The
highlights of that illustrious career include: Playing
in seven consecutive NCAA Championship games
(1977-83), winning three consecutive NCAA Championships(1978,'79,'80), compiling a record of 105
wins and 16 losses, coaching 23 first-team AllAmericans and four Division I Players-of-the-year.
Without a doubt, Chic ranks as one of the game's
best coaches of all time. He left no stone unturned
in his preparations for his team's next game. He was
a very demanding, hard-driving coach who would
accept nothing but the best from his players. Every
ounce of Chic's energy went towards winning. He
would often arrive at his Hopkins office at 6 a.m.
and would routinely leave after 7:30 p.m. He was
as tough a competitor as there has ever been in the
coaching ranks.
Chic was recognized for his accomplishments on
the lacrosse field when he was inducted into the

Lacrosse Hall of Fame on January 30, 1988. How
pleased his family and friends were that this highest
lacrosse honor was awarded to him! And there
weren't two happier and more proud people that night
than his parents. Mr. & Mrs. Ciccarone attended just
about every game Chic played or coached, and they
always beamed with pride over "their Henry."
In like fashion, Chic and his wife Sue took great
pride in their four sons who grew up in the thick of
the Hopkins tradition. But it's rather unique that all
four boys wanted to go to the same school that their
father attended and to also play for him on the
lacrosse field. Henry Jr. and Brent did play for their
dad, but John and Steve were denied that privilege
when Chic decided to enter the business world in the
fall of 1983. Both John and Steve will be playing
their senior years at Hopkins this spring.
. The Ciccarone legend lives on, as do the wonderful memories of Chic's friendship—the light-up
smile, the little stories, the laughs, and the warm
uplift that came from being with him.
Plans are being made for an appropriate memorial
for Chic, along with a get-together on Friday night,
April 28, prior to the Homecoming game with Navy.

Syracuse thinks that they have the talent to repeat
Courtesy of Syracuse Sports Information Dept.
Great expectations will usually do one of two
things—motivate to success or cause such pressure
that the level of perfection expected is unattainable.
Coach Roy Simmons Jr.'s Syracuse Orangemen are
about to discover which road they will travel this
season.
By acclamation, Syracuse is the preseason number
one team in the country. The defending NCAA
champions lost only two starters from last year's team
and more than one person in the lacrosse world has
suggested that the number two team in the country
is SU's second team. The Orangemen return Player
of the Year Gary Gait, twin brother Paul, and Attackman of the Year John Zulberti. All three were
first-team All-Americans last year. Also back is
second-team All-American defenseman Mark
Stopher and honorable mention picks defenseman Pat
McCabe, MVP of the Junior World Games last summer, defenseman Phil Schluter, and attackman Greg
Burns. Returning in goal is the MVP of last year's
championship game, Matt Palumb, who brings a 17-1
career record into the season.
It certainly would appear that another banner year
is in store for the Orange. Syracuse has made a national leading six straight trips to the Final
Four, and the only surprise would be if they didn't
make number seven. But Head Coach Roy Simmons
Jr. remains guarded when the subject of back-to-back
championships comes up.
"A year ago, everyone thought we would be lucky
to be much over .500 because of the large graduation," said Simmons. "But we were hungry, determined, and came out strong. All of the games were
on synthetic surface, which allowed us to play the
uptempo game we like to play. We got the number
one ranking right away with the win over Hopkins
and the 15 games on synthetic fields played right into
our hands. We escaped injuries, the chemistry was
right, and everyone was unselfish.
"Now we've got a look-alike team and everyone.
expects us to repeat. But if you look at it, we're playing the Tigers on the road instead of at home, five
of our first six games are on the road and six of our
games this year are on grass. I realize it's going to
be very difficult to repeat. Everyone will gear their
season towards tripping Syracuse up."
That may well be, but don't count on it happening very often. With the exception ofjust a few key
people, the 1989 Orangemen are the same team as
the 1988 Orangemen—with an added year's experience. This is a team that handed Johns Hopkins
its only regular season loss, a 19-7 demolition at
Homewood. SU beat teams by an average of 10 goals
a game, winning by such scores as 19-7, 23-8, and
23-5 over quality teams like Cornell, UMass and
Navy. Yet the Orange also showed it could win the
tough ones, beating North Carolina in overtime and
Penn in the final seconds of the NCAA semifinals.
From the 15-0 record to Gary Gait's "Air Gait"
leap into lacrosse history to the record crowd of
20,007 for the NCAA championship game in the Carrier Dome, 1988 was a very special year for Orange

On February 22nd, the head coach of the Syracuse
Orangemen, Roy Simmons Jr., spoke with the NewsLetter. We thank Coach Simmons and the Syracuse

ranking?

very bottom and at the top, and I think I like working my way to the top. I don't always like to start
there, because so much is expected of the kids. I don't
like too much pressure on young students or athletes.
I think it's always easier to be the David and not the
Goliath. We're expected to win and be a big, tough
guy, but you know on any given day, we might not
have the hot hand. It's tough pressure for a young
boy.

Next year, after five consecutive years of facing
Syracuse on opening day, the Blue Jays will play the
Orangemen in mid-season, at the Carrier Dome.
Hopkins will again begin the season at home, hosting
the Princeton Tigers.
Mike Morrill will be watching college lacrosse
from a different sideline this year. Hopkins's leading
scorer last season is now an assistant coach at
Princeton. The Tigers' head coach in Bill Tierney,
who was Zimmerman's top assistant for three years
at Hopkins. "Morrill's a real winner. He will help
Tierney a lot," said Zimmerman. Morrill will return
to Hopkins March 25, when Princeton plays the Jays
at Homewood.
The 1989 lacrosse Final Four will be played at
Byrd Stadium, on the campus of the University of
Maryland. The semi-finals doubleheader will be held
on Saturday, May 27, and the championship game
on Memorial Day, Monday, May 29.
In the past, Zimmerman has spoken out strongly
against the NCAA lacrosse championship's Final Four
structure. Since 1986, the national semi-finals and
finals have been held at a single site, only two days
apart, during Memorial Day weekend.
Stating that 48 hours was insufficient time to
prepare for a lacrosse match, especially for the National Championship game, Zimmerman argued for
a return to the previous structure, in which there was
a week between the games.
"I've kind of changed my attitude. The Final Four
has helped the sport," said Zimmerman recently. "A
team does need more time to prepare for the finals,
but the Final Four can be great for the sport of
lacrosse. There is a good turnout and enthusiasm."
The crowd of 20,007 at Syracuse's Carrier Dome
for the 1988 finals was the largest ever at a college
lacrosse match.

Mike's tips and glossary for the lacrosse novice
by Michael Farbowitz
Tomorrow at 2 p.m., when the Johns Hopkins Blue
Jays face off against the defending national champion Syracuse Orangemen at Homewood, they will
begin the 107th season of Johns Hopkins Lacrosse.
If you are a freshman, transfer student, or have just
buried yourself in the MSE all winter, this is the time
when you find out why you came to Hopkins in the
first place. The school spirit is intoxicating, and so
are the pre- and post-game parties. Any and all complaints about Hoppies' general indifference and
"nerd-like atmosphere"(to quote President Muller)
fall by the wayside on spring Saturdays when the Blue
Jays play lacrosse. You generally won't hear people complaining about their tests and papers and you
usually won't hear "I want to go to the game, but
I have a paper due Monday.'' Here are a few tips
to help the uninitiated enjoy the Homewood spring
pastime.
The admission is free, provided you have a valid
JHU ID. Otherwise, tickets are available before game
time at the box office at the entrance to the Athletic
Center. For important games such as tomorrow's and
Homecoming, get to the stadium early, or you'll find
yourself sitting in the nosebleed seats at Conrad
"Gebby" Gebelein Stadium (the permanent
bleachers). Even worse, you might have to sit in the
end zone, or on the side away from the benches,
where visiting fans usually sit. (The University, in
anticipation of large crowds, has installed additional
bleachers on the away side, but those also fill up
quickly for big games.) Also, remember to dress for
the weather, as early season games can be brutally
cold. Take heart, though, since May games usually
provide a good tanning opportunity.
Sorry, Hoppies, but alcohol is not permitted in the
stadium. (But students have been known to be extremely creative.) If, however, you choose to covertly imbibe alcoholic beverages during the game,
beware of the militia of security guards hired to control crowds and confiscate alcohol or items which

can be thrown onto the field.
The game consists of four fifteen-minute quarters
with a fifteen-minute intermission, considerably
shorter that the original Indian version of the game,
which lasted from hours to days. From start to finish,
the game is rarely longer than two hours. Players
are penalized for different infractions, and penalties
result in either a change in possession or a "manup" situation, much like a hockey or indoor soccer
power play.
For those not familiar with the sport, the activity
following a shot on goal that goes out of bounds
seems strange. Players from both teams charge
toward the sideline where the ball has gone out of
bounds. This is due to the fact that on a shot on goal,
the team closest to the ball when the ball goes out
of bounds gains possession of the ball. On a pass,
however, the ball is turned over to the other team.
Often, the judgment of whether an out-of-bounds ball
was a shot or a pass is up to the referee.
Each period begins with a faceoff at the center of
the field. In addition, a faceoff occurs after a goal
is scored. If the score is tied at the end of regulation
time, four-minute sudden death overtimes are played
until one team scores.
Hopkins has dominated the sport since its inception. Here are a few statistics that demonstrate this
point. The Blue Jays have:
—won or shared 42 national championships
—twice represented the U.S. in the Olympic
Games
—won seven NCAA championships since the
tourney began in 1971
That's about it. Along with the enclosed glossary
of the lacrosse vernacular, you are now well-armed
to head into lax territory. Most importantly, have
fun, forget about your exams on Monday, and catch
that Blue Jay Spirit! Go Jays, crush the Orange!

roughness, unsportsmanlike conduct, and the use of
an illegal crosse. Watch for these to see just what
they are. There is a lot of subjectivity in the calling
of these fouls—it depends mostly on the mood of the
referees. The penalty for a personal foul is suspension from the game for one to three minutes, depending on the severity of the foul. The offender's team
plays short-handed during the penalty.
*Expulsion fouls: A player will be suspended for
the remainder of the game for really nasty attempts
to injure or for committing five personal fouls.
However, the penalized team is allowed to substitute
for the expelled player.
*Technical fouls: These are less serious fouls and
other rules violations. These include interference,
illegal screening, holding, pushing, touching the ball
with the hands, withholding the ball from play,
throwing the crosse, illegal procedure (a very broad
category, indeed), stalling, illegal equipment, and
crease violations. The penalty for a technical foul
is either a 30-second penalty (if the offending team
does not have possession of the ball at the time the
foul is committed) or simply loss of possession of
the ball (if the offending team does have possession.)
*Penalty enforcement: A penalized player will
remain off the field (and his team plays one man
down)for the duration of the penalty time unless the
other team scores a goal or the penalized team gains
possession of the ball in its attack goal area.
*Out of bounds: When the ball is thrown out of
bounds by one team, possession is awarded to the
other team, unless the ball was deemed a shot-ongoal that went out-of-bounds. In this case, possession is awarded to the team, one of whose in-bounds
players was closest to the ball when it crossed the
boundary line.
*Crease Privileges:No opposing player is allowed
in the goal crease area at any time. They may reach
into the crease with their sticks to play a loose ball,
as long as they don't make contact with the goalie
or his stick. Furthermore, a defending player, including the goalkeeper, with the ball in his possession, may not enter the goal-crease area. Nor may
he remain in the goal-crease area in possession of
the ball longer than four seconds.
*Time-outs: Each team is allowed to call two
timeouts per half and one per each sudden-death
period. Timeouts can be called when the ball is dead
by either team or by the team with the possession
of the ball in the attacking half of the field. The coach
or the captain of the team can call a timeout.
Well, there you have some of the basic rules of
the game of lacrosse. Some of them may seem sort
of strange to those of you who are new to the sport,
but after you see a few games, you'll get the hang
of it and even start second guessing the refs (who
are almost never right, anyway).

The Second Annual Lax Quiz
Win a stick from
by Michael Farbowitz

Sponsored by STX
"The world's standard of excellence in lacrosse"

Ah, Springtime. Time for romance, flowers,
baseball, and the annual rite of spring for
Homewood, the MCAT. Just kidding. Even more
important than the MCAT is Hopkins lacrosse,
when Hoppies forget about their homework and
emerge from their subterranean carrels on D-level
to cheer for one of Division l's best lacrosse
teams. Well, here's a chance to show everyone
how much you know (or think you know) about
Hopkins lacrosse. Some of the questions are really easy, others border on the impossible, but all
are answerable, using the resources available on
campus (i.e. being really good friends with a lax
player). The person who submits the entry with
the most correct answers by 4 p.m. Wednesday
to the Gatehouse (News-Letter Office) will be
declared the winner. Ties will be broken using a
random drawing. This week's prize is not just a
case of beer and a certificate for groceries at a
local food establishment, but a prize more befitting the topic of the quiz. Females get a date with
the lacrosse player of their choice, and males get
a date with the girlfriend of the lacrosse player
of their choice. Just kidding, we wouldn't ask the
lax players to give that much of themselves to
Hopkins, they take enough punishment on the
field as it is. The real prize is a lacrosse stick,
donated by STX. The News-Letter is not responsible for any broken windows caused or fire
alarms activated by the winner's misuse of the
prize. Answers will be printed in next week's issue.
Good Luck, and GO JAYS! CRUSH THE
